node.title: Does execute_on = 'ALWAYS' not supposed to work with post processors?
node.bodyText:
When running the MWE below: We should expect both PP to have the same value?
Postprocessor Values:
+----------------+----------------+------------------------+
| time           | num_elems_total| num_elems_total_always |
+----------------+----------------+------------------------+
|   0.000000e+00 |   1.600000e+01 |           0.000000e+00 |
|   1.000000e+00 |   1.600000e+01 |           0.000000e+00 |
+----------------+----------------+------------------------+

[Mesh]
  [mesh]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    nx = 4
    ny = 4
    nz = 0
    zmax = 0
    elem_type = QUAD4
  []
[]

[Variables]
  [u]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [u_aux]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []
  [v_aux]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [force]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = t
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [diff]
    type = Diffusion
    variable = u
  []
  [force]
    type = BodyForce
    variable = u
    function = force
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [right]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = u
    boundary = right
    value = 1
  []
  [left]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = u
    boundary = left
    value = 0
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  num_steps = 1
  dt = 1
  solve_type = PJFNK
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [num_elems_total_always]
    type = NumElems
    elem_filter = 'TOTAL'
    execute_on = 'ALWAYS'
  []
  [num_elems_total]
    type = NumElems
    elem_filter = 'TOTAL'
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  csv = true
[]

Hello
Yes that looks like an omission.
ALWAYS kind of has to get hardcoded in every execute_on check to make it work. It's not programmatically made to be always, which is annoying
Guillaume

I had found it problematic for output already
#19255
Just stay away from 'always'
I ll create an issue
I take the blame on this. I created this for functor execution and didn't really consider its use outside of it

umm with that context, I think the fix might to remove it from the general list of execute_on flags.
and only add it back for functors.
what do you think?
sounds good to me

I ll put up a PR.
Thanks for reporting Max, this is very helpful.

node.title: New MOOSE update does not recognise files
node.bodyText:
Hello, I have reinstalled MOOSE and I am receiving some errors when running old simulations that were working before the update. The procedure that I was following before was creating the necessary files that I needed and I was adding them to the "materials" directory in Blackbear for "src" and "include" directories. Then I was running "make" in Blackbear to include these new files for my simulations. I know it is not the most common way to do it but it was working fine and it was the easiest way because they were only 2 files.
I have tried to do the same now but it seems like the functions from the added files in Blackbear are not recognise and I am receiving errors such as:
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "k_func", of type "PiecewiseLinear".
A parameter was passed for an option using data from a CSV file but the 'data_file' parameter has not been set. This is not allowed
Is it because I am not including correctly other modules? I have tried to change the Makefile and set it to include all modules, but it is not working. I am running the simulation as:
mpirun -np 20 path/blackbear/blackbear-opt -i MaterialDeposition.i
Thank you in advance.

Hello
I modified these parameters last month.
MOOSE was silently ignoring  piecewise tabular (linear/constant) function parameters that were set and not used. You will need to adapt your app. Are you already using the latest BlackBear version?
My guess is that you set the data_type parameter while using input file xy data
data_type is only used for the CSV input
Guillaume

Thank you! I am indeed using the latest BlackBear version, I have changed some things and now it is working, but I have another error regarding the type for a phase-field simulation. I am trying to run a phase-field simulation but it tells me that the PolycrystalSolidKernel needs a type (it is a new action), but when I am using the normal Polycrystalkernel included in MOOSE I do not see that error message. Do you know why this could be?
*** ERROR ***
path/solid.i:19: missing required parameter 'Kernels/PolycrystalSolidKernel/type'
Doc String: "A string representing the Moose Object that will be built by this Action"
Is it a MooseObjectAction ? MooseObjectAction use the type required parameter

*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "k_func", of type "PiecewiseLinear".


A parameter was passed for an option using data from a CSV file but the 'data_file' parameter has not been set. This is not allowed

I improved the error message for the next person who ll hit this. Thanks for reporting this problem.

I googled this issue and many posts suggest that missing libxcb* libraries  can cause this issue. So I discussed this issue with our HPC Admin. We performed following steps a couple of times
export QT_DEBUG_PLUGINS=1
peacock

and found that libxcb-render-util.so.0 libxcb-image.so.0 libxcb-icccm.so.4  were missing.
Now, peacock is working smoothly.
Thank you very much for your help!

node.title: Euler angles and rotation matrix in ComputeElasticityTensor
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose team,
I use "ComputeElasticityTensor" to simulate the elastic deformation around a circular tunnel in a transversely isotropic rock (layered rock). The geometry of the model is shown schematically below.

In this example, the isotropic plane is tilted 45 degrees about the y-axis and the rock medium has an initial isotropic stress of 30 MPa. With these assumptions, we can define the orientation of roke layers by assuming "euler_angle_1=90" and "euler_angle_2=45" (the input file is attached).
My first thought was that the "euler_angle_3" doesn't play a role here, since it only describes the rotation of the isotropic plane (around the axis of anisotropy). But I saw that changing the euler_angle_3 has a significant effect on the deformation pattern around the tunnel. Figure below shows the displacement magnitude for three different values of euler_angle_3:

Only the results for euler_angle_3=90 look reasonable! However, a small change in the ComputeElasticityTensor.C file produces exactly the results I expect.
I changed:
RotationTensor R(_Euler_angles); // Type R: RealTensorValue.
// Rotate the elasticity tensor
_Cijkl.rotate(R);
to:
RotateTensor R(_Euler_angles); // type R: RealTensorValue.
// Rotate elasticity tensor
_Cijkl.rotate(R.transpose());
With the above change in the rotation matrix, the elastic deformation becomes independent of euler_angle_3 for transversely isotropic materials.

Could you please review the rotation matrix in the ComputeElasticityTensor.C file and let me know if such a change is needed or not? i also attached the input file (+mesh)
Best regards,
Kavan
TransverselyIsotropic.zip
@tonkmr @jessecarterMOOSE on the elasticity tensor

Gotta be really careful here to get what you want. This has tripped me up many times. MOOSE uses a specific Euler angle convention (there are a lot) which assumes both specific axes being rotated about and the ordering. Be sure to read the documentation on this (link). It matters if you're rotating the material to a specific orientation or if you're rotating the axes. I believe the default in MOOSE is to use the latter. Your modification is likely assuming the former, which is why you want the transpose. There is an example in the documentation similar to this where the negative of the desired angle is needed, which amounts to a transposed rotation matrix (for a single rotation).
If I'm understanding your problem, you want to rotate about the y-axis, but MOOSE uses the Z-X-Z convention for Euler angles 1, 2, and 3. It may be easier in your case to instead provide the rotation matrix (or the transpose of it) to ComputeElasticityTensor (again see the docs on how to do this). Or you could re-orient your problem so the desired rotation is about the z-axis.

Dear @jessecarterMOOSE,
Thank you very much for your answer and useful hints. As far as I know, MOOSE uses the Z-X'-Z'' convention (this is also clear from RotationTensor.C). Actually, I wanted to adopt this approach to define the orientation of geological structures (faults, stratifications, rock layers ...) with respect to the global coordinate. In engineering geology, any plane rotated in the x-y-z coordinate is described by only two rotation angles: 1) the dip direction (rotation about Z) and 2) the dip angle (rotation about X'). In other words, the third rotation about Z'' does not change the principal material coordinate. If I understand you correctly, the Euler angle approach may not be directly applicable to these applications. I guess I will follow your suggestion and provide a rotation matrix resulting from only two rotations (Z and X').
Thank you again, Kavan

The ordering of the rotations may still be an issue here (see intrinsic vs extrinsic rotations on the Wikipedia page for Euler angles). Maybe what you want is this?
euler_angle_1 = 0
euler_angle_2 = 45
euler_angle_3 = 90

Exactly! I changed the order of the rotations from 1-2-3 to 3-2-1. Now the material response (deformation pattern around the tunnel) has become independent of the last rotation (euler_angle_1). This is exactly what I expected for a transversely isotropic material ;) thank you very much for your help.

Dear @jessecarterMOOSE ,
In the documentation it is only stated that extrinsic rotation has to be used for euler-angles input. Does the matrix also have to be extrinsic?
Thanks in advance,
HoWil
I believe the rotation matrix, $R$ that you enter gets applied to the elasticity tensor, $C$, directly like: $RCR^T$, so it is up to you to generate the proper rotation matrix

To my knowledge a rotation matrix does also hold the information if the rotation is extrinsic or intrinsic. So the results for the rotated tensor and e.g. the resulting strain will be different if you insert an e.g. matrix for an active-extrinsic rotation instead of an active-intrinsic one.
I compared the results for the rotated tensor and resulting strain with results from python (scipy, pytransform3D + matscipy), COMSOL, and OOF2 (where I used Bunge notation). The results match if I use an intrinsic and active rotation (matrix).
Can you confirm that using active and intrinsic definition of the rotation for matrix-input is correct?
EDIT: I did compute passive-extrinsic Euler-angels out of my active and intrinsic rotation matrix and do get with these angles directly fed into MOOSE the same results.

My understanding is that it is up to the user to determine what the proper orientation for their system is. If for instance, you have a precipitate phase embedded in a matrix, you could choose to either rotate the precipitate clockwise or rotate the matrix phase counterclockwise. Both are valid and you have the the ability to do either.

node.title: Control system on Array variables
node.bodyText:
Hi there!
Im trying to apply control system to a Neumann boundary and I tried applied RealFunctionControl + RealControlParameterReporter with a standard variable and it works well. But when I apply the same logic to an array variable, it failed. Im aware that there are differences between scalar variablr and array variable even if there is only one component in array variable, but I cant find a better set of functions to use. Can you guys help me out?
Thanks!
Hi @pengfejeac the difference is that value is declared as controllable in NeumannBC but not in ArrayNeumannBC. Would you feel comfortable modifying the code to make that controllable?

Oh sorry, it will not be that simple. I didn't realize at first that value is a RealEigenVector parameter so objects like RealFunctionControl won't work with it. @zachmprince @YaqiWang has anybody done anything with controlling RealEigenVector parameters to your knowledge?

Hi @lindsayad, thanks for your response! I did some small experiment about this lately. If the RealEigenVector contains only a few values, then I can modified the source file of boundary condition and add a few controllable Real variable to construct the RealEigenVector. But this method will not very ideal if the RealEigenVector is relatively large. So it's not quite helpful.

node.title: Libmesh for newapp
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I am generating a newapp from scratch using the MOOSE phase field module.
Next, I have to integrate libmesh with the newapp. Since I am entirely new in this field, would you be kind to advise me, how I can build libmesh for a newapp, and integrate it with the app executable!
I appreciate your time.
Best regards.

Hello
Please follow the application development tutorial. The instructions on how to create an app show you have to use the stork script for that
Guillaume
libmesh is a dependency of MOOSE. It is already integrated in any MOOSE application

node.title: General MOOSE capabilities
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
Iam trying to develop diverse coupled Multiphysics models for COR-EOR and CO2 storage processes using different MOOSE module. Please I need assistance in ticking Yes or No on the capabilities that applies to MOOSE.

Hello
Do you mind creating a Google doc or something easier to work with ?
Guillaume

Hi GuidGiud,
Thanks for help, I have kept a google doc link.
https://docs.google.com/document/d/11HaMZWq__qiRubsbD-eGIg1vRlGpwgyWBa5Mvp2t5BQ/edit?usp=sharing
@1runer @rpodgorney could you please help out here
@cpgr too please

I can't edit the document, but I think you can put a yes for all fluid flow; yes for all transport except electrochemical and colloids; yes for the geochemistry except for Davies and Pitzer and the isotope ones; yes for the microbial (will have to double check but I think this is correct); yes for coupling except electrical double layer; yes for operator splitting and global implicit, FE and FV for spatial discretisation, heaps of options for time discretisation.
Not sure what you mean exactly by high peclet transport - do you mean some sort of stabilisation? Also not sure about elasto-plastic cap model so probably a no for that one.

@POLonge please make sure edit rights are pretty loose so the community can pitch in
Thank you

mamba-init-error.txt

Jens

what does  echo $SHELL return ?

node.title: PorousFlowRelativePermeabilityConst for single phase flow
node.bodyText:
Problem
I'm running single phase Porous Flow simulations and hoping to speed them up.
I thought I wouldn't need relative permeability in the single phase case, as phase disappearance shouldn't be a problem, and so tried a constant relative permeability of 1. This worked fine for a small 2D test and did actually reduce the run time, but as soon as I tried it on a more complex geometry, it would only get through one or two nonlinear iterations before failing to converge (Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_NANORINF iterations 0 -> Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINEAR_SOLVE iterations 1).
As a compromise I returned to the Corey version, and bumped n down to 2 (and even 1) as suggested in the page on nonlinear convergence. This also failed to converge and only works with a minimum value of n = 3. I also (briefly) tried using FLAC, as it was faster than Corey on the simpler case, however that too failed on the more complex case.
What is likely to be causing this to happen, and is there a way I can get around it?
Background
I'm actually simulating a fluid being injected into a completely dry porous medium, which isn't something directly supported by the Porous Flow module. I've written a custom "capillary pressure" user object, which calculates saturation on a curve between $S\approx0$ at $P=0$ and $S\approx1$ at $P=2P_f$ (where $P_f$ is some nominal pressure at the flow front).
This approach is working pretty well, and I've validated it against some analytical cases, however at the mesh resolutions I require (based on convergence studies with my material properties) the run times are far too long.
Hence I'm trying to simplify any aspects of Porous Flow not applicable to my case, relative permeability appearing to be a low hanging fruit. Incidentally if there are any other suggestions for simplifications/optimisations I could make, I'd love to hear them!

Hello
Please try these general instructions for solving convergence issues.
Initializing better & picking direct solvers is likely going to help
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/application_usage/failed_solves.html
Guillaume

Thanks for the link - I had followed some of the advice on that page already, this time I tried using FDP as suggested and it did indeed converge, apparently indicating the Jacobian needs to be "fixed".
To be honest I'm not sure why using a simpler relative permeability formulation would break the Jacobian, and even less sure how I'd go about fixing it, but I will do some more research and have a go. Absolute worst case I can use the slow (n = 3) version.
I don't think I can initialise any better, as my only variable (P) is set to a global IC of 0 which is the physical reality. I have also been running with the direct lu and mumps which hasn't helped.
ok so if the Jacobian isnt great, did you try PJFNK instead of Newton?

I'm pretty sure that the derivatives for the constant relative permeability are correct 😄. I suspect that when you use a non-constant relative permeability with the exponent ramped up, that the curve gets flatter, relatively perm gets smaller and the flow slows down significantly, making it easier to solve.
You have your own capillary pressure - we do use the derivative of that in the Jacobian. Did you get them correct? And are you using the the PorousFlow1P material to compute saturations?

Thanks both for the input - PJFNK also has the same problem with constant/low order relative permeability unfortunately.
Okay that makes sense. I am using PorousFlow1PhaseP to compute saturation, and I'm pretty sure I've got the derivatives correct (checked on Wolfram and Desmos):
effectiveSaturation -> 1 / (1 + std::exp((pf - pc) / _epsilon))
dEffectiveSaturation -> (std::exp((pf - pc) / _epsilon)) / (_epsilon * std::pow(std::exp((pf - pc) / _epsilon) + 1, 2))
d2EffectiveSaturation -> (std::exp((2 * pf + pc) / _epsilon) - std::exp((pf + 2 * pc) / _epsilon)) / (std::pow(_epsilon, 2) * std::pow(std::exp(pf / _epsilon) + std::exp(pc / _epsilon), 3))
Where pc is the pressure*, and pf is the nominal flow front pressure I mentioned above.
I should note that I've set capillaryPressureCurve and its derivatives to return 0 as I'll never use this object in a porepressure-saturation formulation.
* I'm a little confused by this - afaik pc is supposed to denote capillary pressure, however in PorousFlow1PhaseP only the porepressure seems to be passed in to the saturation calcs (I had thought $P_c=-P$ in the 1 phase case). I don't think it helps that I'm working in absolute pressure and so negative pressure doesn't make much sense. Regardless, using the positive pressure value to calculate saturation has worked for me so far.
From this discussion it seems the runtime easy wins I had hoped for might not be so straightforward - thanks again for the help though.

node.title: Resources for Learning FEA in Solid Mechanics
node.bodyText:
Maybe this isn't the right location for this discussion. If it is not, let me know and I can take it down (or you're welcome to delete it).
I'd really like to learn more about the nuts and bolts of the mathematical theory behind solid mechanics FEA simulations. I've really been trying hard to read about FEA and plasticity, but it doesn't seem to be "clicking" for me yet. I have a good intuition for what is going on in the background but I don't have a great understanding for the actual system of equations and solution sequence that are being solved.
I have a copy of the "Introduction to Computational Plasticity" book that is often referenced here. It does seem like a good book that I'm able to mostly follow, but I just wish there were some more examples and problems to work through. I also have a hard time following complex mathematical proofs without good examples and problems to work through to put it together.
To the seasoned moose solid mechanics experts: Is there a certain reference/references, detailed example problem, or university class/classes that helped bridge the gap for you?
I'm just rambling at this point, but I think a good book idea would be describing in extreme detail one "cycle" of a simple 3D solid mechanics FEA problem. It could cover in detail something like a simple 3x3x3 3D mesh with some some simple boundary conditions. It could be broken up similar to how moose presents the Plug-n-Play system (i.e., 1) Compute Strain, 2) Compute the Elasticity Tensor, 3) Compute Stress... etc). The theory could be taught, but also, we could be working towards solving the one simple example problem throughout the book.
TLDR - I want to understand but don't currently. I'd like to know the best references that helped you see the light.
